subject: Re: [junit] Re: Making good use of testing effort
msgSnippet: The design sketch in my head wouldn t have any custom subclasses of Runner involved, but you might mean something else.  If you d like to flesh out your ideas
messageBody:
The design sketch in my head wouldn't have any custom subclasses of
Runner involved, but you might mean something else. If you'd like to
flesh out your ideas a little more, I'd be happy to give feedback.
Good luck,

David Saff

On Mon, Feb 1, 2010 at 1:12 PM, Loritsch, Berin C.
<berin.loritsch@...> wrote:
> I think it appears that what I need to do is create a runner to collect
> the classes and the methods. Â After that, it is a matter of executing
> the tests defined in the test "prototype" I've created.
>
>
>

>>>>
>>>> I've got a challenge that I'm not sure how to approach with JUnit 4.
>>>> I've sort of hacked something similar in JUnit3, but there were some
>>>> inelegant things about it.
>>>>
>>>> Basic problem is that I have a bunch of setters and getters on my
>>> domain
>>>> models that have predictable side effects. Essentially, the model
> has
>>> a
>>>> listener infrastructure and if the user changes the value of the
>> class
>>>> attribute the appropriate event is supposed to fire. The typical
>>>> setter/getter looks like this:
>>>>
>>>> class MyBean extends Listenable {
>>>> String value;
>>>>
>>>> public String getValue() {
>>>> return value;
>>>> }
>>>>
>>>> public void setValue(String newValue) {
>>>> fireAttributeChangedEvent("value", value, newValue);
>>>> value = newValue;
>>>> }
>>>> }
>>>>
>>>> I need to test that the setters fire the appropriate event, and that
>>> the
>>>> event attribute name is correct. I want a test harness to
> essentially
>>>> collect all the setters and getters and change the value to ensure
>>> that
>>>> the event is sent as expected. Then I want to run that against all
> my
>>>> domain models.
>>>>
>>>> My understanding is that I need to generate a suite, and add the
> test
>>>> instances to that suite. I've upgraded to JUnit 4 because I think it
>>> is
>>>> designed better. I'm just at a loss as to how to start. With JUnit
> 4,
>>>> individual tests are marked with an annotation.
